PermaFrost NMR® Performance Report
International Bank A
June 12, 2013 
Executive Summary
         This report contains specific information regarding the installation of the energy control measure 
(ECM) PermaFrost NMR® in [Brazil Location] for International Bank A. Detailed forensic performance testing 
(outlined later in this report) was performed on 8 DX units ranging from 15 to 40 tons in size. It was 
determined to demonstrate the performance of the product in both administrative and branch type 
buildings.
Immediately following the baseline testing, all the units were treated with the proper amount and type of 
PermaFrost NMR® product formulated for R-22 DX and R-438A systems. Since there were no other ECM’s 
going on during this pilot project, the improvement in efficiency and restored capacity gained directly at the 
units is solely attributable to the PermaFrost NMR® ECM. The unit(s) now provide cooler/drier supply air 
while using less power. This greater operational efficiency is due to the restoration of the heat transfer 
ability of the evaporator and condenser coils.
Energy Science Division

Product Brief
         PermaFrost NMR® is a multi-patented nanotechnology surface chemistry Energy Control Measure 
(ECM) that uses Nucleo Molecular Regenerative (NMR) technology as its core agent. A sustainable, 
one-time treatment with no down time required, PermaFrost NMR® lasts for the remaining life of any 
type of system in which it is installed. Examples of the types of commercial HVACR systems and 
equipment that PermaFrost NMR® has proven success with are direct expansion air systems (DX); 
chilled water systems (both flooded and DX; air and water cooled); ice making equipment; ammonia 
refrigeration plants (single compressor and cascade) and variable refrigerant flow (VRF) designs. The 
equipment utilized in these systems within our expanding portfolio of clients includes centrifugal (single 
and multi-stage), scroll, reciprocating and screw configurations.
The direct benefits of PermaFrost NMR® are improved cooling performance, increased capacity and 
improved refrigerant velocity – all of which allow systems to achieve set point temperatures in a more 
rapid fashion which reduces compressor operating periods. The indirect benefits resulting from the 
enhanced thermodynamic characteristics following treatment include reduced run time, less kW hours 
used, less amp draw at the compressor, longer equipment life cycle time and a reduced carbon footprint 
for International Bank A.

Measurement and Veriﬁcation Protocol
The International Performance Measurement and Verification Protocol (IPMVP) was utilized in the 
development of this report. The Association of Energy Engineers (AEE), American Society of Heating, 
Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), and The Efficiency Valuation Organization 
(EVO) accept the IPMVP as a global methodology for determining the effectiveness of energy conservation 
methods and products.
There are four distinct options in the IPMVP protocol for energy conservation professionals to utilize. They 
are options A, B, C and D.  Retrofit Isolation (Option B) was the option used for this report. Retrofit Isolation 
(Option B) is defined as: All parameter measurement with the boundary of the ECM (PermaFrost NMR®) as 
the single source of measurement. Savings are determined by field measurement of the energy use of the 
energy conservation method affected equipment or system and any performance enhancements versus the 
baseline data.
Measurement frequency ranges from short term to continuous, depending on the expected variations in the 
savings and the length of the reporting period.  For the boundary utilized for Option B short-term 
measurements are very useful as data when the variables are contained. The savings are calculated by 
short-term measurements of baseline and reporting period energy, and /or engineering computations using 
measurements of proxies of energy use.
The final computation follows the formula:
Energy Science Division
Option B savings = Baseline Energy – Reporting Period Energy
+ - Routine adjustments / + - Non-Routine Adjustments

Energy Conservation Method (ECM) Content
The content of the following report will demonstrate the effects of PermaFrost NMR®’s ability to correct the 
effects of thermal degradation and fouling on the heat exchange surfaces. 
It was determined with International Bank A to treat 8 DX units. A diagnostic examination of the pilot equipment is 
implemented to determine if the unit’s operational conditions are satisfactory. Baseline measurements were  
recorded and then the proper amount and type of PermaFrost NMR® was injected. The product was 
allowed 4 weeks to seat itself into the metal surfaces. At the end of this gestation period, Post M&V results 
were taken in the identical manner as in the baseline, taking special care to match the same or very similar 
entering air temperatures and compressor discharge pressures. These are the two most critical 
measurements affected by the weather. Some units in this report required normalization due to weather.
The following report produces the utilization of the IPMVP International Performance Measurement and 
Verification Protocol as the M&V plan. The final calculations and measurements were performed by 
Powertron Global’s Forensic Mechanical Engineer, [Senior Energy Engineer] and the equipment analysis and 
product installation was overseen, conducted and verified with International Bank A employees Mr. [Bank Representative] and Mr. 
[Bank Representative].
The results were formulated by entering the data into the following thermodynamic engineering formulas:
 
 
kW= Volts X Amps * 1.47 Three Phase / 1000
 
 
Btuh Capacity = Measured CFM X 4.5 * Calculated Enthalpy Delta 
 
 
System Eﬃciency % = Actual Coil Capacity Btuh / Nominal Coil Capacity Btuh
 
 
kW per Ton = Measured kW / Measured Tons
 
 
COP = 12 / kW per ton / 3.412

It was discovered that the Bitzer package unit #1 was low on refrigerant. It was evident that this unit had a 
leak(s). 10 lbs of R-22 gas was added to the unit in the post trip. The unit certainly showed significant 
improvements but the unit did not get the full exposure of PF due to this leak(s).

Utilizing the data in the above charts, the following performance measurements were placed into the 
regression analysis to account for the restored capacity brought about by PermaFrost NMR® and to 
determine an accurate ROI for implementing this ECM:.
Regression Analysis 
Adjusted Base Tonnage         20.22 tons (equates to tonnage in ERP)
Adjusted Total Watts         926 Watts per Ton * 20.22 tons = 18,723.7 Total Watts
Adjusted Base kWh         (18,723.7 Watts /1,000) * 1,482 Annual Operating hrs = 27,749 kWh
Revised Cost to Run Prior to ECM         27,749 kWh * $.2098 = $5,821.42 USD
Post ECM kWh         (15,098.9 Watts / 1,000) * 1,482 Annual Operating hrs = 22,377 kWh
Cost to Run After ECM         22,377 kWh * $.2098 = $4,694.60 USD
Cost Savings per Year         ($5,821.42 - $4,694.60) = $1126.82 USD
Cost of PermaFrost NMR® $3,087 USD
KwH Saving per Year         ($27,749 - 22,377) = 5,372 kWh
Environmental Impact of the Project         * 3.8 metric ton reduction of carbons dioxide emissions
*Emission factor calculated by 7.055 x 10 to the negative 4 metric tons Co2/KwH
Source: EPA 2012 eGRID2012 Version 1.0

Utilizing the data in the above charts, the following performance measurements were placed into the 
regression analysis to account for the restored capacity brought about by PermaFrost NMR® and to 
determine an accurate ROI for implementing this ECM:.
Regression Analysis 
Adjusted Base Tonnage         24.48 tons (equates to tonnage in ERP)
Adjusted Total Watts         860 Watts per Ton * 24.48 tons = 21,052.8 Total Watts
Adjusted Base kWh         (21,052.8 Watts /1,000) * 1,482 Annual Operating hrs = 31,201 kWh
Revised Cost to Run Prior to ECM         31,201 kWh * $.2098 = $6,545.87 USD
Post ECM kWh         (14,367.3 Watts /1,000) * 1,482 Annual Operating hrs = 21,292 kWh
Cost to Run After ECM         21,292 kWh * $.2098 = $4,467.04 USD
Cost Savings per Year         ($6,545.87 - $4,467.04) = $2,078.83 USD
Cost of PermaFrost NMR® $4,116 USD
KwH Saving per Year         ($31,201 - 21,292) = 9,909 kWh
Environmental Impact of the Project         * 7.0 metric ton reduction of carbons dioxide emissions
*Emission factor calculated by 7.055 x 10 to the negative 4 metric tons Co2/KwH
Source: EPA 2012 eGRID2012 Version 1.0

Utilizing the data in the above charts, the following performance measurements were placed into the 
regression analysis to account for the restored capacity brought about by PermaFrost NMR® and to 
determine an accurate ROI for implementing this ECM:.
Regression Analysis 
Adjusted Base Tonnage         44.07 tons (equates to tonnage in ERP)
Adjusted Total Watts         897 Watts per Ton * 44.07 tons = 39,530.8 Watts
Adjusted Base kWh         (39,530.8 Watts /1,000) * 5,256 Annual Operating hrs = 207,775 kWh
Revised Cost to Run Prior to ECM         207,775 kWh * $.2098 = $43,590.08 USD
Post ECM kWh         (26,626.8 Watts / 1,000) * 5,256 Annual Operating hrs = 139,951 kWh
Cost to Run After ECM         139,951 kWh * $.2098 = $29,361.83 USD
Cost Savings per Year         ($43,590.08 - $29,361.83) = $14,228.25 USD
Cost of PermaFrost NMR® $8,232 USD
KwH Saving per Year         ($207,775 - 139,951) = 67,824 kWh
Environmental Impact of the Project         * 47.9 metric ton reduction of carbons dioxide emissions
*Emission factor calculated by 7.055 x 10 to the negative 4 metric tons Co2/KwH

Conclusion / Notes
The nominal capacity for the HVAC units in this report were determined by the manufacturer at the 
conditions of incoming condenser water at 85 degree F and entering evaporator air temperature of 80 
degrees F. The conditions during this M&V procedures were less than the design parameters, which 
accounted for the capacities well above design even before the ECM PermaFrost NMR® was installed. 
These conditions were present in both baseline and post (Energy Reporting Period) periods therefore the 
improvements PermaFrost NMR® brought about are sound and scientifically verified.
The runtime and electric energy cost (0,43R$ with all Brazilian taxes) was informed by [Bank Representative]  (from Branches department) and [Bank Representative] (for Administrative department) and moreover that 
consideration was taken in the equipments 60% of the total runtime only.
The total cost of PermaFrost NMR® was calculated based on the price with all the Brazilian taxation, as well 
as, trading company costs included which reached out the value per unit of $ 205,8USD.
Following the treatment of PermaFrost NMR®, the installed units (8) showed a substantial reduction in 
Watts/energy of 47.1%, the average improvement in COP was 44.7%, the average overall system efficiency 
and Btuh capacity improvements were 38.0% and the total restored capacity was 54.5 tons.
In conclusion, regarding the ECO efficient/sustainable respect to this project International Bank A saved the 
environment 149 metric tons of green house gas emissions -carbon dioxide- as well as saved 210,592 kWh of 
power.
